title: Tenses
introduction: Tenses are verb forms that indicate when an action takes place. There are three main tenses, each with four subcategories.

content.value: Simple Present (Verb + s)
Used for current action.
She writes a book. He plays cricket.
Present Continuous (am/is/are + verb + ing)
The action is continuous at present.
She is writing a book.
Present Perfect (has/have + past participle form of the verb)
The action started in the past but continues or has consequence in present.
She has written a book.
Present Perfect Continuous (has/have + been + verb + ing)
The action started in the past but is still ongoing in present.
She has been writing a book for two hours.
Simple Past (past form of the verb)
Action ended in the past.
She wrote a book.
Past Continuous (was/were + verb + ing)
She was writing a book.
Past Perfect (had + past participle form of the verb)
She had written a book before lunch.
Past Perfect Continuous (had + been + verb + ing)
She had been writing a book for two hours before lunch.
Simple Future (will/shall + present verb)
She will write a book.
Future Continuous (will/shall + be + verb + ing)
She will be writing a book.
Future Perfect (will + has/have + past participle form of the verb)
She will have written a book by tomorrow.
Future Perfect Continuous (will + have + been + verb + ing)
She will have been writing a book for two hours by then.

exercises.title: Identify the Tense
exercises.instructions: Identify the tense used in each of the following sentences.

questions.question: She writes a letter every day.
They are watching a movie right now.
We had completed the project before the deadline.

exercises.title: Fill in the Blanks
exercises.instructions: Fill in the blanks with the correct form of the verb in the specified tense.

questions.question: By next year, she __________ (complete, Future Perfect) her degree.
I __________ (work, Present Perfect Continuous) on this project for three months.
They __________ (travel, Past Continuous) when the storm started.
